{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3435618,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-16T17:26:35.919Z","cooked":"

Does anyone know of a cheap USB to CAN bus bridge that works with Phoenix? Does anyone know if the SparkMax will do this already??? I know it does the function‚Ä¶

I want to build a test/train box that has a beefy DC supply, breakers, motors, and some way to hook it to a computer. This will get used for kids to study PID tuning and such.

I hate to put a $300 CANivore in it‚Ä¶ Of course I‚Äôve already got two SparkMaxes, a NEO, a NEO550, and soon a $200 Kraken in it

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-10-16T17:26:35.919Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":445,"reads":369,"readers_count":368,"score":2313.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":473172,"topic_slug":"cheap-usb-to-can-bridge","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/cheap-usb-to-can-bridge/473172/1","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3435621,"name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","username":"kingc95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-16T17:32:14.316Z","cooked":"

Canable (when it‚Äôs in stock, i.e. not now) works for connecting to CAN 2.0 over USB. This worked for TalonSRX and previous gen CTRE motor controllers. I found it as a recommendation before the CANivore was released and before CAN FD was the new protocol.

Openlight Labs

CANable Pro 1.1: Isolated USB to CAN adapter

The CANable Pro 1.1 is a fully isolated open-hardware CAN to USB adapter manufactured in the USA. Connect to any CAN2.0A/B network without worrying about common mode offset, ground noise, or damaging your computer! ÔªøNote: the Pro 1.1 is equivalent to...

Price: USD 70.00

docs.ctre-phoenix.com

Prepare Linux Robot Controller

Why prepare Linux Robot Controller?: Preparing a Linux robot controller allows CAN Device control without a roboRIO for non-FRC use or as a secondary processor that can also directly control CAN De...

Doesn‚Äôt work with Kraken see more posts below and I‚Äôm not sure about talking with Neos. From my memory (it‚Äôs been a few years, 4 years it looks like in my notes) the only reason I was able to control a CTRE motor controller or talk to a Gadgeteer sensor was their library was also installed and supported the canable/USB CAN. If REV doesn‚Äôt have similar support in their library, or a version of their library usable outside of a roborio I‚Äôm not sure what it will do.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-10-17T02:22:55.832Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":368,"readers_count":367,"score":133.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":473172,"topic_slug":"cheap-usb-to-can-bridge","display_username":"Mr. Siefen | 453","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://openlightlabs.com/collections/frontpage/products/canable-pro-1-1-isolated-usb-to-can-adapter","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"CANable Pro 1.1: Isolated USB to CAN adapter ‚Äì Openlight Labs","clicks":62},{"url":"https://docs.ctre-phoenix.com/en/stable/ch06b_PrepLinuxRobot.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Prepare Linux Robot Controller ‚Äî Phoenix documentation","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20632,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mr. Siefen"},"post_url":"/t/cheap-usb-to-can-bridge/473172/2","custom_user_title":"Mr. Siefen","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3435629,"name":"","username":"person4268","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/22d042/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-10-16T17:43:35.955Z","cooked":"

(I am ignoring CAN FD mostly)

The most ‚Äúmight already have the parts for it‚Äù is gonna be a microcontroller like a Pi Pico paired with a cheap can transceiver board (note that most have a terminator soldered on). You can run the USB->CAN bridge mode of Klipper (a 3d printer firmware). Note that such a setup isn‚Äôt fully featured (it basically supports nothing but passing can frames along and receiving them), but it quite literally cost me $2. There are some cheap Canable clones floating around on Aliexpress that you could try too. No idea if they‚Äôre reliable or a good idea though, I have zero experience with them.

Also note that Phoenix only supports SocketCAN devices on only Linux so whatever device you do settle on needs to run Linux.

REV doesn‚Äôt have any real support for using real motors outside of an FRC robot context. Internally they use GitHub - REVrobotics/CANBridge: Generic CAN Bridge emulating FRC netcomm CAN driver for connecting a PC to the CAN Bus with WPILib 2020+ and SPARK MAX (FW 1.5.0 or higher) or other drivers, currently only supported in Windows. for Rev Hardware Client, and it can in theory be plumbed into a simulated C++ robot project (look at the tests), but I have not tried this, is certain to be unsupported, there is no documentation on this, and it only supports Windows.

(Also, side note, please make sure you have a good, rapidly accessible, and definite way to disable it, motors spinning in ways they shouldn‚Äôt are terrifying when you‚Äôre near them)

I‚Äôve used a knock of canable with spark maxes and it does work but rev does not provide official library support for that currently.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-10-16T18:27:00.438Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":216,"readers_count":215,"score":68.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":473172,"topic_slug":"cheap-usb-to-can-bridge","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/cheap-usb-to-can-bridge/473172/6","custom_user_title":"Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3435818,"name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","username":"kingc95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-17T00:07:47.613Z","cooked":"

You may just be out of luck and need a CANivore. Can FD is not as common to find ‚Äòcheap‚Äô out in the wild. Other CAN FD adapters are actually more than the CANivore‚Ä¶

Another contender for CAN 2.0 though (and this one appears to be in stock), so not all bad news. I haven‚Äôt used this from Odrive, but I have used their other hardware and trust the quality of hardware and firmware.

ODrive Robotics

ODrive USB-CAN Adapter

A plug-and-play USB to CAN adapter, perfect for controlling ODrives and any other CAN devices.

Price: USD 37.00

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-10-17T00:09:36.230Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":8,"reads":192,"readers_count":191,"score":113.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":473172,"topic_slug":"cheap-usb-to-can-bridge","display_username":"Mr. Siefen | 453","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://shop.odriverobotics.com/products/usb-can-adapter","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":33}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":46443,"username":"Weldingrod1","name":"Rod","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20632,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mr. Siefen"},"post_url":"/t/cheap-usb-to-can-bridge/473172/7","custom_user_title":"Mr. Siefen","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3435840,"name":"guineawheek","username":"guineawheek","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/guineawheek/{size}/180797_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-17T01:26:07.109Z","cooked":"

I would also vouch for the ODrive CAN adapters ‚Äì they‚Äôre basically Copperforge VulCANs with slightly different connectors and running the gs_usb compatible firmware, and those perform reasonably well. I use them every day and I haven‚Äôt ever had issues with them.

ive had a lot of success with this DSD-TECH can adapter (basically a generic CANable)

i currently am using the canable fw for it but will eventually switch to the candlelight since it is a little faster and uses gs_usb instead of slcan. depending on fw, you can use either linux or windows

the rev canbridge thing works with this, take a look at this CD post.

What were the issues you were having with canable and Kraken?

It‚Äôs been a bit since I‚Äôve personally tested non-CANivore for Kraken but it should work.

Docs: Installing Phoenix 6 (non-FRC)

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2024-10-17T01:59:30.860Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":145,"readers_count":144,"score":39.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":473172,"topic_slug":"cheap-usb-to-can-bridge","display_username":"Dalton","primary_group_name":"CTRE","flair_name":"CTRE","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/1/b/1bd2b430e1bb6427d1c6504ff6abcd31de851a6d.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":57,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://v6.docs.ctr-electronics.com/en/stable/docs/installation/installation-nonfrc.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Installing Phoenix 6 (non-FRC)","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":20632,"username":"kingc95","name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61981,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"CTR Electronics"},"post_url":"/t/cheap-usb-to-can-bridge/473172/11","custom_user_title":"CTR Electronics","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3435849,"name":"Nathan Zhou","username":"NathanZhou","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nathanzhou/{size}/225374_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-17T02:03:10.841Z","cooked":"

Per CTRE recommendation, CANivore is recommended. However any socket CAN adapter could be used.

v5.docs.ctr-electronics.com

Prepare Linux Robot Controller

Why prepare Linux Robot Controller?: Preparing a Linux robot controller allows CAN Device control without a roboRIO for non-FRC use or as a secondary processor that can also directly control CAN De...

Also this thread might give you more information.

Controlling CTRE CAN motor controllers directly from a Raspberry Pi, without a RoboRIO Technical Discussion
My team is building an offseason robot (for showing off at recruiting events) consisting of a basic west coast drive frame with a recliner chair mounted on top. The person sitting in the recliner holds the joystick to control the ‚Äúrobot‚Äù. (We‚Äôre calling it the world‚Äôs fastest couch.) Having an entire Windows computer with its own independent battery sitting on the robot communicating via WiFi to the same robot seemed a little silly to us, plus we wanted to learn something new, so we decided t‚Ä¶
Question about CTRE Hardware-Attached Simulation for robotoy Programming
For Java and cpp, I know I could have a CANivore attached for Hardware-Attached Simulation. Any idea for how to get this done in robotpy? I know I could use robotpy -sim to start a simulation but that‚Äôs it.

For your setup, I am not sure if any of the CTRE device would work with other brands under the same CAN bus. You might need multiple CAN adapter for handling more than one bus for devices from different vendor.

Siefen | 453","username":"kingc95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png","created_at":"2024-10-17T02:16:07.729Z","cooked":"

I haven‚Äôt tried it, I was just under the impression the Kraken is CAN FD not CAN 2.0 so it‚Äôs not meant to work between the two (why a CANivore doesn‚Äôt see TalonSRX as well). The CANable in their docs states it‚Äôs only 2.0 so I assumed it‚Äôs not gonna work. If you have had luck with Krakens on a 2.0 I‚Äôll definitely stand corrected and would love to know what the process was. I have a CANivore in my personal stock, but the team went REV for our swerve so it didn‚Äôt get used this last season. I don‚Äôt have any CAN FD devices personally otherwise to try it with my CANable.

When I was using CANables daily I was driving TalonSRX with brushed motors and the magnetic encoders with ‚ÄòGadgeteer‚Äô connection to the motor controller. The Falcons had just come out, but they were too few in stock for the project I was working on.

The Kraken (TalonFX) supports and detects CAN 2.0 and FD, otherwise it wouldn‚Äôt work on the roboRIO bus. Same for all of our Phoenix 6 supported devices.

The TalonSRX only supports 2.0 hence why it doesn‚Äôt work with the CANivore as it‚Äôs an CAN FD to USB adapter.

Note that not all CAN adapters are equal and I‚Äôve used some pretty flakey ones.

I‚Äôm looking for a cheap item to build into a test bed.

The ideal thing is to have a USB plug that goes into a computer running Phoenix. The other end goes into my test bed and crosses over the USB to the Kraken‚Äôs CAN bus so we can train kids on tuning and running Krakens.

It sorta sounds like y‚Äôall are saying ‚Äúyes, a CANable USB to CAN 2.0 bridge will do this‚Äù.
